Label.Text: [b]Label the structure of the antibody and the antigen[/b]

Container.ExtendedTooltip: Allows you to take a controlled volume of the liquid from one container and place it into another - remember to use clean tips!

StartConversation.ConversationSentence: Your pipette tip has already been used and could contaminate reagents and reactions. Always use a clean tip!\nContamination can ruin the experiment.
You need to have a tip on your pipette in order to collect liquid.\n\nOtherwise the pipette will be contaminated and ruin the experiment.
You will need this clean Eldon stick
You need a new Eldon stick for the next test.\nThrow away the used one in the trash bin.
Good laboratory practices include the use of pipettes to add liquids.
The Eldon stick has already been used.\nPlease discard it and use a new one to prevent cross-contamination.
Please use Eldon stick only for the unmixed circle.

Conversation.Sentence: Welcome to Labster! A novel teaching platform for exploring the world of biotechnology.

So glad you made it! This is the Antibodies Lab! In this lab you will learn the basics about antibodies and you will help a young couple to identify the risk of Rhesus disease.\n\nDr. Lee is asking for you in the consultation room, let's go!
[m][b]Dr. Lee:[/b][/m] Hello, I am Dr. Lee, the obstetrician. How can I help you today?
[m][b]Joel:[/b][/m] Hi, Dr. Lee. We are here today because my wife is pregnant with our second child and we are a bit worried.
[m][b]Carmen:[/b][/m] We have [m]read[/m][say]red[/say] about Rhesus incompatibility and that this could cause problems during pregnancy.
[m][b]Joel:[/b][/m] Can you tell us more about Rhesus incompatibility and the risk for the baby?
[m][b]Dr. Lee:[/b][/m] When having the second child, if the baby is Rhesus-positive, the pre-formed anti-Rhesus antibodies can cross the placenta and enter the fetal bloodstream.

[m][b]Dr. Lee:[/b][/m] The antibodies attack the fetal red blood cells with the Rhesus antigen. In the worst case this can lead to hemolytic disease of the newborn or short HDN. It is characterized by a decreased level of red blood cells.
[m][b]Joel:[/b][/m] Thank you for your explanation. Is there anything we can do to test for a potential Rhesus incompatibility?
[m][b]Dr. Lee:[/b][/m] Absolutely! I will schedule for a blood test to identify your Rhesus statuses to see if further treatment is needed.

Joel and Carmen are expecting their second child and want to find out if there is Rhesus incompatibility between Carmen and the baby.\n\nDr. Lee has tasked you to review their case, so let's get started!
Would you like to start a short Tutorial on how to use the LabPad and navigate through the lab?

Option.Sentence: Yes, I am playing LABSTER for the first time.
No, I know how to use the LabPad.

Conversation.Sentence:
The LabPad will guide you through the virtual lab and will store all the information you collect while playing.

You are currently in the "[b]Home[/b]" tab. Here the instructions and quiz questions will be displayed.

Click "[b]Continue[/b]" to proceed. Make sure you read the information carefully - you won't be able to access it anymore after you click "[b]Continue[/b]".

[b][/b]
Images are stored in the [b]"Media"[/b] tab.
In the virtual lab you will be working with dangerous chemicals.
Take a look at the warning symbol on this flask! This means that the flask contains corrosive chemicals.
Click on the blue [b]"View Image"[/b] button below to identify other hazard symbols you might find in the lab.
[b][/b]

[b][/b]
Open the [b]"Theory"[/b] tab to access more information. You can read about what you have to consider when working with corrosive chemicals here.

Great work! [b][/b]
You can track your progress in the [b]"Mission"[/b] tab. You will see all the completed tasks listed there. Use it if you want to get an overview of your work in the lab.

You can also see your [b]PROGRESS[/b] and the [b]virtual lab time[/b] on the top right of the LabPad. You are very efficient and start working early in the lab, 8:00 am everyday!

Good job! Now you know how to work in the lab. If you ever get stuck somewhere or if you want to take a break you can [b]exit the lab[/b] from the button at the top center, and continue from the last checkpoint. Let's get started with today's mission.
Awesome! Now that you're all dressed up for the experiment, you're ready to help Joel and Carmen.

[b][m]Marie:[/b][/m] Hey there! I'm Marie! Before we start with your quest let's talk a bit more about the key players in this mission: antibodies!

[b]Antibodies[/b] are super important when it comes to protecting your body from viruses, bacteria and other harmful substances.
Each antibody binds to a target called [b]antigen[/b]. Together they form a unique antibody-antigen complex.
It may help to imagine the antigen as a lock and the antibody as single key for the lock.
[b][m]Marie:[/b][/m] Antibodies are also known as immunoglobulins or short Ig. They are Y-shaped proteins. Let's have a look at the structure of an antibody in the molecular viewer.
Here you can see a hologram of an antibody, just like the one which causes problems in Rhesus incompatibility. Isn't it a beautiful Y-shaped molecule?
An antibody consists of two long chains called heavy chains and two short chains called light chains.
Can you see the different chains in the hologram? The heavy chains are colored in green/turquoise and red/orange. The light chains appear in yellow and blue.

[b][m]Marie:[/b][/m] Every antibody is unique, just like a fingerprint! It's produced to detect a single antigen. Binding of the antibody to the antigen happens through a distinct region at the tips of the Y also known as [b]variable region[/b]. This region is different for every antibody and specifically binds to an area called [b]epitope[/b] on the antigen.

[b][m]Marie:[/b][/m] In mammals there are five different classes, or [b]isotypes[/b], of antibodies:[m][b] IgA, IgD, IgE, IgG, and IgM[/b][/m][say]eye gee A, eye gee D, eye gee E, eye gee, G, and eye gee M[/say]. They are categorized according to their biochemical properties and fulfill different functions in the body.

See how the classes differ in their shape and organization.
[b][m]Marie:[/b][/m] Let's see if you can identify the structures of an antigen and an antibody.
Perfect! You have labelled all the parts of the antibody and antigen correctly.
No this is incorrect, please try again.
Hmm, looks like you need a bit of help! Click on the 'Theory' tab to see the structure of an antigen and an antibody.
When an antibody binds to its matching antigen, it forms a tight complex. There are two parameters which determine how efficient the antibody binds to the antigen.

They are: [b]affinity[/b] and [b]avidity[/b].

Affinity describes the strength of a single antibody-antigen contact site.

Avidity describes the sum of affinities of multiple antibody-antigen contact sites.

[m]IgG[/m][say]eye gee G[/say] has a strong affinity for its antigens. [m]IgM[/m][say]eye gee M[/say], on the other side, has low affinity but high avidity.
Let's watch an animation to understand how the mother's immune system specifically produces antibodies against the Rhesus antigen of the baby and how an antibody-antigen complex is formed.
This is a fetal red blood cell. On its surface are Rhesus antigens also known as D antigens.

Upon first encounter of the Rhesus-negative mother's immune system with the fetal blood, B cells produce specific IgG antibodies targeting the D antigens on the surface of the red blood cells. The body has established an immunological memory.
During the second pregnancy, if the child is Rhesus-positive, these antibodies recognize the Rhesus antigens on the red blood cells.
They build a tight antibody-antigen complex. Let's take a closer look at what happens at its interface.
In every antibody-antigen complex, there are four main types of bonds that can be formed:
Hydrogen bonds,
Electrostatic forces, or ionic bonds,
Van der Waals forces,
And hydrophobic interactions.
Awesome! You now understand the basic concept of antigens and antibodies.
Before we determine the Rhesus status for Carmen and her children, we need to know how to conduct the blood test and interpret its results.

[b][m]Marie:[/b][/m] The blood typing test we will use is based on the two most commonly used blood grouping systems: the [m][b]ABO[/b][/m][say]A B O[/say] group and the [b]Rhesus[/b] group.

Depending on the presence or absence of A and B antigens on the red blood cell's surface, a person either belongs to A, B, AB or O. Blood groups that are positive for Anti-D are assigned Rhesus positive. Following this classification, a person with blood group A+ would have A antigens as well as D antigens found on its red blood cells.

[b][m]Marie:[/b][/m] Do you know your blood type?

Knowing a person's blood type is extremely important in the case of blood transfusions. When a patient receives blood from a donor with an incompatible blood type, [b]agglutination[/b] will occur. This means that the red blood cells will clump, which could be lethal to the patient.

For example: If a person with blood group B donates blood to a person with blood group A, agglutination will occur creating clots in the blood vessels. This happens because the recipient's body produces anti-B antibodies that will bind to antigen B on the red blood cells of the donor's blood.

Let's get started with the blood typing test and determine the blood type of four different patients who are waiting for a blood transfusion from a matching donor.\n\nThere are four Eldon cards in front of you. Each of the circles on the cards contains antibodies for a specific blood antigen. If a matching antibody-antigen pair is formed during mixing blood, cells agglutinate. That is how we can determine, which blood group the sample belongs to.
The lab assistant has prepared the remaining Eldon cards for you, and placed the blood samples on the corresponding cards.
Well done! Look at the test circles! Some of the blood drops don't look as soluble as before but precipitated. This is called agglutination.
Agglutination is also known as blood clotting. Blood clots are for example formed when you injure yourself. The clots prevent excessive loss of blood by 'sealing' the injury site.
Alright, have a go at labelling the Eldon cards from the experiment you just did!

Zoom into the individual Eldon card, and select the correct blood type from the drop down list. Remember to take the Rhesus factor (designated with + or -) into account.


Have you labelled the test cards?

Zoom into the individual Eldon card, and select the correct blood type from the drop down list. Remember to take the Rhesus factor (designated with + or -) into account.


Have you labelled the test cards?
Excellent! You're an expert on blood typing! You now understand the principles of compatibility in blood transfusions.
It seems you haven't labeled all Eldon cards correctly. Please try again.
Looks like you need a bit of help! Click on the 'Theory' tab to read about the antigens and antibodies present in the different blood types.
It seems you haven't labeled all Eldon cards correctly. Please try again.
Looks like you need a bit of help! Click on the 'Theory' tab to read about the antigens and antibodies present in the different blood types.
Let's apply these principles to help Joel and Carmen to determine if there is a Rhesus incompatibility between Carmen and her second child.
To determine a potential Rhesus incompatibility we need to first identify the Rhesus status.
We have collected the blood sample from Carmen and her first child. We have also done fetal blood sampling from the fetus by withdrawing blood from the umbilical vein.
Let's perform blood typing for Carmen, her first child, and her second child.\n\nThe lab assistant has already prepared the Eldon cards with a drop of water on each circle.
The lab assistant will prepare the rest of the blood samples for the remaining Eldon cards.\n\nObserve the cards when she is done.
Well done! Now we know the Rhesus status for Carmen, her first child, and her unborn second child.

[m][b]Marie:[/b][/m] Let's review what we've learned.\n\nWe know the basic concepts about antibodies and antigens, and that compatibility is important during blood transfusion. We also know that Rhesus incompatibility can be a problem during pregnancy.

[m][b]Marie:[/b][/m] We can now confirm that there is Rhesus incompatibility between Carmen and her child. Let's go back to the hospital consultation room to tell Joel and Carmen what we've found out.
[m][b]Dr. Lee:[/b][/m] Hi, welcome back. We have determined the Rhesus status for you and your children.

[m][b]Dr. Lee:[/b][/m] After performing the blood test, we have found that you are Rhesus-negative, while both your first child and second child are Rhesus-positive. This means there is a Rhesus incompatibility.
[m][b]Carmen:[/b][/m] Oh dear! Is there any treatment?
[m][b]Dr. Lee:[/b][/m] Yes there is. RhoGAM injections have been developed to treat Rhesus incompatibilities during pregnancies. These injections are small dosages of anti-Rhesus antibodies.
[m][b]Dr. Lee:[/b][/m] The dosage is low enough such that it does not harm the fetus, and high enough to prevent the immune system from producing more Rhesus antibodies.
[m][b]Joel:[/b][/m] Sounds great! We would like to make a schedule for the injections. Thank you so much for your help!

Congratulations! You have completed the Antibodies Lab, and helped Joel and Carmen determine the Rhesus incompatibility.

Carmen has given birth to a healthy baby girl!

Your results will be saved showing the [b]100%[/b] completion.\n\nPlease fill in the feedback survey by clicking the "Continue" button below (it will take you 1 minute). We will use your feedback to keep improving Labster. If you want to give us even more feedback, you can use the "Help" button.
Are you done exploring?

Option.Sentence: b) No, I want to explore more.

Conversation.Sentence: Thank you for your feedback!

Task.Title: Introduction to the LabPad
Task.Instructions: Learn how to use the LabPad.

Task.Title: Learn how to access the relevant theory
Task.Instructions: In the "Theory" tab you can access the relevant theory at any time.
The quiz questions need to be answered in the "Home" tab.
Pick up a lab coat from the rack.\n [b] Click here for more info [/b].
Task.Description:
You can always click the LabPad to obtain more information about a task.

How to wear a lab coat:
 1. Make sure you are in the center view of the lab.
 2. Click on the lab coat rack to pick up a coat.

Click on the lab in the background to swipe down the LabPad.

Task.Title: Find a glove box and put the gloves on
Task.Instructions: Well done! Now find a glove box and click on it.\n [b] Click here for more info [/b].
Task.Description:
How to wear gloves:
 1. You are in the center view of the lab.
 2. Click on a workbench to go there.
 3. Locate a glove box,
 if there are no glove boxes click "[b]BACK[/b]" in the top right corner to
 move to another workbench.
 4. Click the glove box when you find it to put the gloves on.

Click on the lab in the background to swipe down the LabPad.

Task.Title: Mission tab explained
Task.Instructions: We can speed up the lab time.
Click on the "[b]BACK[/b]" button to step back into the center of the lab.
Task.Description: If you are looking at a workbench or a machine you can always go back by clicking on the "[b]BACK[/b]" button in the top right corner.

Task.Instructions: Click on the LabPad to answer the quiz question.
Click on the labcoat rack to wear a labcoat.
Click on the ANTIBODY button to observe the structure of an antibody.
Task.Description: Click on the ANTIBODY button.

Task.Instructions: Click here when you're done exploring the structure.
Please, move to the center of the lab.
Task.Description: Leave the pipette on its holder and then go to the center of the lab.

Mission.Title: Identify the structure of an antigen and an antibody

Task.Description: Click on the keyboard of the laptop.

Task.Instructions: Label the different parts of the antibody and the antigen.
Task.Description:
1) Click on the letters.

2) Select the correct word from the drop-down menu.

3) Click 'Submit' when you're done.

Mission.Title: Learn how an antigen-antibody complex is formed
Understand the basic principles of blood typing

Task.Instructions: Please, move to the center of the lab.
Task.Description: Leave the pipette on its holder and then go to the center of the lab.

Task.Instructions: Protect your hands and the experiment by wearing gloves.
Task.Description: Click on the glove box to put on gloves.

Task.Title: Prepare the Eldon card
Task.Instructions: Pipette a drop of water onto the circles of Eldon card 1. [m]Click here for more information.[/m]
Task.Description:
Water is used to activate the antibody sera on the Eldon card.

1) Take up a small amount of water. Remember to pick up a pipette tip before pipetting.

2) Click on Eldon card 1.

3) Place a drop of water onto all four test circles. One pipette tip holds enough water all circles.

Task.Instructions: Pipette Blood Sample 1 onto the circles of Eldon card 1. [m]Click here for more information.[/m]
Task.Description:
1) Take up a small amount of blood.

2) Click on the Eldon card 1.

3) Place a drop of blood onto all four test circles. One pipette tip holds enough blood for all four circles.

Task.Instructions: Use an Eldon stick to mix the blood sample within the test circles of card 1.
Task.Description: Take an Eldon stick and zoom into Eldon Card 1. Click one of the test circles to mix the blood. Each Eldon stick can only be used once. Remember to discard it after you're done.

Task.Instructions: Click on the arrow to observe the result of the neighboring card.
Task.Description: Zoom into the Eldon cards to observe the result. Click on the arrow to move from one card to another.
Discard your used gloves to prevent cross-contamination of other samples, lab equipment and personal belongings.

Mission.Title: Continue to understand the basic principles of blood typing

Task.Instructions: Select the correct blood type from the drop-down list.
Task.Description: Select the correct blood type from the drop-down list.

Task.Instructions: Label the blood types on the cards. Click here when you're done.

Mission.Title: Apply the principles of blood typing to Rhesus incompatibilities

Task.Instructions: Please, move to the center of the lab.
Task.Description: Leave the pipette on its holder and then go to the center of the lab.

Task.Instructions: Protect your hands and the experiment by wearing gloves.
Pipette a drop of blood onto the test circles of Eldon card 'Carmen'.
Task.Description: Take up a small amount of Carmen's blood sample and pipette it on the four circles of the Eldon card named 'Carmen'. One pipette tip holds enough blood for all circles.

Task.Instructions: Use an Eldon stick to mix the blood sample within test circle Anti-A.
Task.Description: Take an Eldon stick and zoom into the first Eldon card. Click test circle Anti-A to mix the blood. Each Eldon stick can only be used once. Remember to discard it after you're done.

Task.Instructions: Click on Eldon cards: Carmen, First child, and Fetus to observe them.
Task.Description: Zoom into the Eldon cards to observe the result. Click on the arrow to move from one card to another.
Discard your used gloves to prevent cross-contamination of other samples, lab equipment and personal belongings.

Mission.Title: Continue to apply the principles of blood typing to Rhesus incompatibilities

Task.Instructions: Label the blood types on the cards. Click here when you're done.

Mission.Title: Discuss your findings with Joel and Carmen

Task.Instructions: Please, move to the center of the lab.
Task.Description: Leave the pipette on its holder and then go to the center of the lab.

Task.Instructions: You have completed the Antibodies lab.
